course.subject: MECH
course.name: Design and Manufacturing I
course.description: Introduction to the engineering design process and engineering graphics; design specification, concept generation, and concept evaluation; geometric construction, sketching, orthographic projection, auxillary views, sectioning, dimensioning, tolerancing, and working drawing. For students under the four-year degree only.

reviews.author: takeyourlife300
reviews.title: The most useless course I have ever taken in ust
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly circles around basic design and manufacturing knowledge. But they are completely incoherent and irrelevant to each other (basically useless), making the content the worst part of this course.

The labs are a bit better but that's not saying much, revolves around simple techniques on using solid works and drawing components and mating them together. Can be fun at times but most of the time you would be dealing with bugs which can be really frustrating.

And the most useless part of the course: we were required to submit a report on how to build a new pedal kart that has better functionality. You'll learn basically 0 knowledge in this part and just try to compile a bunch of useless knowledge together just to reach the 40 pages mark. They want you to come up with innovations for a pedal kart but since its such an old and ubiquitous technology you'll have a really hard time trying to find ways to do just that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Attended the lectures once and never attended them again, the lecturer was basically mumbling on his own and it was extremely difficult to understand him given his heavy accent. The ppts were also just a bunch of random information combined, making it really hard to know what were the main takeaways in each lecture (if any).

Labs were okay, though the TA taught really slowly and once helped a student debug his drawing for 20 minutes, leading to a 30 minutes delay of the class, (Delays happen almost every lab session)

Also, no clear instructions were ever given on how the report was to be done, a blurred outline only emerged after students bombarded their questions on the discussion board, still, most of us had no idea what was expected from us.
reviews.comment_grading:
The quiz accounted for 20% of the course, and it revolved around random pages on the ppt slides and was, again, basically useless. One question required you to recite the modulus of elasticity of steel and aluminium and I for one cannot see the value of testing student's ability to memorise an entire property table.

The other 80% comes from the group project, although no clear instructions were given, you could still have a decent mark if your groupmates were decent enough since nobody had any idea what we were supposed to do anyway
reviews.comment_workload:
The individual report takes most of the workload, you will be required to come up with 40 pages of pure BS since no directions were given, you'll probably spend half of the time wondering what you're supposed to do.

The group report was a bit better since you basically just pick the best BS among yourselves and compile it into another report.

There will also be a presentation of your ideas, which doesn't really matter that much as long as your report is good enough.

Weekly solid works assignments will also sometimes be given though those are usually relatively easy.

reviews.author: GK
reviews.title: Basically you are studying two courses at the same time.
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture is about design and manufacturing. You will learn basics about design like engineering design, tolerance and manufacturing like casting, extrusion etc. Basically the content in lecture are not actually tested in final exam, nor related to the project at all. Since there are PRS questions, you have to practice your ctrl f skills. The term "blended learning" means that you have to attend the lesson on time to take prs, but the lecturer will cover the material again ==.
Solidworks will be taught in tutorial and will be very useful especially on the report.

Tutors are all local so communication was not really a problem at all.
reviews.comment_grading:
Though hard work, every one near me were getting A range. Reports are easy to A and not academic at all.
Final grade is just similar to the other MECH course, which are the only good thing of MECH course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is huge Not only would you need to attend all the lectures and lab, but you also need to do two terribly long reports. In addition to the already terrible workload in MECH2210, MECH2410 and MECH2040, you will be experiencing a much more chur semester that you ever had. But don't worry, you will be even more chur in year 3.
Exam are open book so you don't need to study for the notes. Study for your google skills.

reviews.author: hihisafaaa
reviews.title: one of the useless course in mech department, a big waste of time
reviews.comment_content:
There are 5 topics in this course, sharing by Engineering specification, dimension and tolerancing, Material property, material selection and design for assembly. These powerpoints are useless in learning as you cannot understand the teaching material by only looking at those ppts. Some of them are even vague even you go to lectures on time to listen to the lecturer's explanations, which makes great confusion to students as there are no clear examples.

The labs were better, you can understand the basic solidwork skills when you attend all the labs. However, this is definitely not enough for students to the pedal kart solidwork drawings, i.e. the skill of advance mating and analysis of forces, stresses in parts drawing.
The angriest part in this course is that most of the pedal kart subsystem details were taught after the submission of the phase one report, and lecture does not provide any useful resources or examples for the pedal kart report, which make students frustrated in its content, and it is even a COMPULSORY course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The accent of the lecturer makes students difficult to catch up and fall asleep. With those unclear PowerPoint notes, students are not able to understand the teaching target. This makes a poor experience for students who attend the lectures and feel meaningless to attend the lectures.

Labs were better as the host is a Hk TA, and you can hear his instruction clearly from his accent. However, it is hard to catch up(don't know it is whether my problem or not) the solidworks step once students were not focusing on his drawing and may miss some of the important steps. It is preferable to look at the lab recording if students cannot follow up in the lab live and feel inconvenient to ask questions while disturbing other's procedures.

Conclusion: watch lab record, and lectures are useless
reviews.comment_grading:
20% grading for 2 quiz, 80% for reports and presentation

Quizzes: Have you imagine that one of the questions is asking for the name of one specific cutting tool and it locates in one slide corner only? These questions are meaningless like asking for the elastic modulus of iron alloy and recognize the stress-strain curve for a particular type of material. Unless you cheated or you are talented like Asperger syndrome that can memorize all detail at once you see the PowerPoint slide, you are not going to make them correct.

Reports: You are going to make a pedal kart for racing and you have to submit a report for the design analysis of your design of pedal kart including the plan of the subsystem in phase one (40 pages), and another group report for the finalized design of pedal kart including the integration of the subsystems from teammates.(45pages) And finally, a 15 minutes' present for the pedal kart students design. Since there is little information provided by tutors to guide the students' pedal kart design, students are less likely to take marks by both reports and presents.

Conclusion: your marks gonna be low due to this stupid course grading which is tailor-made to bully students
reviews.comment_workload:
Workloads are definitely one of the highest among all courses in HKUST. The tutor will remind students to prepare for the phase 1 report 3 weeks before they submit, but it is not enough as students have to type 45 pages and to research for many subsystems. The deadline of report crash with the date of the quizzes by themselves and making the workload of the report's deadline week huge, making most students give up for the preparation of the quiz. Moreover, the instruction from the notes provides by the tutor contradicts with the tutor's words on the phase 1 report workload explanation. This increases students' workload a lot.

Phase 2 report was mainly based on phase 1 and the workload is relatively smaller than phase1, but it is hard to "blow water", i.e. students have to give data like numbers to explain the design, which is hard to work on.

The presentation is different from the report that many of the parts cannot directly copy from the phase 2 report, telling you that the report that students had made is meaningless.  

Lab is the easiest part if students do the assignment on time by spending 1-2 hours.

Overall the workload is extremely high due to the meaningless report that used up your quiz revision time. AND THE COURSE IS CUMPLUSORY FOR MECH DEPARTMENT STUDENT!

reviews.comment_workload: Horrible. It has all the workload a course can possibly have. mid and final exam, assignment, project, presentation, in-class quiz. You will have to manage your time well.

reviews.author: homing
reviews.title: A botched attempt at Blended Learning
reviews.comment_content:
The course was divided into 3 main parts:

1: Lectures
Lectures are basically useless. Since there is no exam and there are no assessments regarding the material covered in class, there is simply no reason to attend the classes unless you are eager to learn and is willing to wake up for a 9am lesson. I personally did not have the endurance it takes.

2: Labs
This is the key part of the course. It takes you thought the things you need to know in Solidworks, which is what the course is built around. You will be have to attend every one of them (or attempt to attend every one of them). They are pretty useful, and you simply have to follow video instructions which provide step by step guidance. (And Stanley is very friendly so you can just ask if anything comes up)

3: Online Lectures
This is where it gets weird. The online lectures are compulsory, since every week there have been quizzes about the online quizzes. They generally introduce concepts of manufacturing and processes, which have nothing to do with the final project.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I guess the course was new to blended learning and thus did not get much of the things right.

Video demonstrations are good, but the volume is rather low compared to the background music (which is now burned into my mind)

Online lectures are low in production quality, in the sense that the professor's voice was not adequately fed into the microphone. These are things that might be changed in future cohorts..
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite good. Given our group was the first to actually show a Solidworks project that resembles a complete car, the instructors seemed to be impressed with our group. Hence an A was achieved.
reviews.comment_workload:
One Online Quiz every week. Takes 15-20 minutes each
Lab work can be completed in class.

Our project looks us 3 complete days before presentation, and another week for the final report.

Presentation in the middle of the course, 15 minutes timed.
50 Page Final report.

Material Properties

reviews.author: UGH
reviews.title: You can't avoid it anyway
reviews.comment_content:
Content itself is actually really interesting and will be useful in the future. Unfortunately MAE department has placed this course in Spring semester therefore some students will understand better when they have done Industrial training during winter. Sadly also the lectures materials aren't used as much in the group project so the course itself is pretty distinct.
My group project was about a pedal kart design and it at least is something pretty interesting however they changes sometimes or every year I supposed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures are only once every week and they have changed the course syllabus in this semester so it will be each of the professor teach a half.
You won't need much help from the professor because just by doing the basic will take you most of the time. Michael and Robin are pretty kind on explaining to you if you ask them on what do they expect and for advices, but then be prepared they actually expect like a TON.
reviews.comment_grading:
While there only one quiz so grading is much reply on the project. The grade came out alright for me but in a group project in 3- 4 people in one group you pretty much know one or two of them doesn't deserve the grade they got.
Report cost a lot more while you you won't need your CAD model to be perfect. It could have been better if they would consider CAD model as part of the grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
VERY VERY high, unbelievably high you question yourself why did you choose MECH at the first place.
While the first half of the project is an individual report which does cost quite a lot like 30% i remember. The group project is nightmare.
Advices? Start EARLY, get started after you read this review get started before you other midterm and exams comes otherwise you will find yourself doing it i the middle of the night and have no studying done for other courses (usually you take 2040 and 2210 at the same time and boy, its difficult)
Advices 2, pray for good group mates, reason to pray is because they require you find your group mates in the same lecture AND lab session and you know its hard to swap. There is not much you can do about it so when you first know you classmate from canvas then start asking.

reviews.author: WYKEI
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
Engineering Design – Creative process; Design specification; Design evaluation; Product Lifecycle Management; Design Portfolio
Engineering Drawings - Communication tool; Drawing standards; Orthographic projection; 3D drawing
Dimensioning and Tolerancing – Basic concepts; Dimensional tolerances - Limits and fits, Cummulative tolerances; Geometric tolerances and measurement
Material Selection -Types of materials; Design for X (Strength, Deformation,..);
Material Specification and EvaluationDesign Evaluation: Quality function deployment
Design for Assembly
Design for Manufacturing
Design for Manufacturing:Primary manufacturing processes - Mold and die related processes (casting, molding, forming, sheet metal forming, powder metallurgy, composite manufacturing)Secondary manufacturing processes: Machining processes: (turning, drilling, shaping, milling, grinding and abrasive processes, non-traditional and thermal cutting processes)
Tertiary manufacturing processes – surface finishing processes (cleaning and surface treatments, coating and deposition processes)

reviews.comment_content: Teaching content is very board, covering the basic element of design and manufacturing, such as the material, tolerance, machinery and design scheme. The course required a group project, in that semester is about a warehouse robot.
reviews.comment_teaching: professor is fully experienced, they can always question all the all answer. BUT, the TA seems not very familiar with the course content so their teaching is kind of confuses. Also, the TA and Professor is not welly communicated

Even the project, the TAs would not follow the guideline or the professors' said. Although the average grading was good, this is no grading guideline on it so it is hard to follow

reviews.author: Richard L
reviews.comment_content: The content is very much what you will expect from a "Design and Manufacturing" class. Very informative, relevant, and also interesting. Topics covered: drawings (tolerance, GD&T, surface finish), material selection, material processing, design for X.
reviews.comment_teaching: This semester, I think they made the wrong decision to use "Blended Learning" as the teaching method of this course. In-class teaching becomes rushed and a bit repetitive (since you would already read and research about the topics covered in the PowerPoint yourselves). Besides these, Professor Matthew and Vincent both are very knowledgeable in all of the topics they talk about.
reviews.comment_grading: One project, two reports, and in-class quizzes every lecture (used for attendance check). Fair grading -- what you would expect basically. Feedback for the reports are a bit vague.
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload, not because of the project, but because of the "Blended Learning". The project itself (warehouse robot) is quite fun, but the self-learn topics are a bit too much to handle for self-learning. For those who really want to learn about concepts of design and manufacturing, and do not want to just blindly cram stuff into your head every week, do NOT take this course IF it is offered in blended learning style -- it is a bit too much.

reviews.comment_teaching:
some of the worst I've ever had.
Prof keeps rambling fancy words in sentences that don't really make sense, but you still need to listen to figure out what he secretly wants in is reports.

very vague when giving assignments, and gives last minute explanations, so you cannot really manage your time well. He can change submission deadline at any random time and doesn't give any detail as to what he wants and how the reports are graded.

labs are pointless if you know solidworks, if you don't, you should practice in your own to get satisfactory level or hope your teammates can use it. but in the lab alone you don't learn much about CAD to be able to use it professionally.
reviews.comment_grading:
- lab attendance : as long as you demo, it's fine, you don't need to sit through the entire lab

- exams are easy but you need to be familiar with the slides. because many people aren't, the grading is quite good.

- reports: for good grade you will need: decent English, good organisation, detail drawings and some good amount of research. 1 submission per group, but some parts inside the report must be individual.

- presentation not graded but requires submitting slide deck. 5 teams get picked to present.
reviews.comment_workload:
CANNOT CHOSE TEAMMATES, team of 4-5.
- open computer finals and midterm, with examples uploaded beforehand: the exam is super similar to those examples but the prof usually doesn't even mentions when he uploads stuff  so you need to pay attention.

- 2 group reports (midterm report, final report): quite heavy, requires a lot of writing. Prof isn't explicitly specific about what he wants but if you listen to what he talks about you will figure out the report content he wants (he always repeats the same words), and do it according to the ppt he uploads.

the reports require to be able to use Solidworks just enough to produce an output.

reviews.author: jc2048
reviews.title: Rubbish course, just don't take it if not necessary
reviews.comment_content:
There are 3 parts to the course
1. Learn how to use SolidWorks to do 3D drawing
2. Learn knowledges about manufacturing and assembling, eg specifications, manufacture & assemble methods
3. Design a pedal kart for a competition

In the course, 1 and 3 will be talked about in lab sessions, while 2 is from the lectures.

1. SolidWorks
In the lab session, TA will teach you how to use basic functions of SolidWorks to do simple 3D drawings, such as drawing, extruding, evaluating mass and cog etc.
Each lab will include a piece of 3D drawing with specifications, and you have to submit it as lab assignment. Some of the lab sessions are drawing practice and one drawing test, so there are only a few lessons that you will be actually learning 3D drawing.

2. Lectures
The lectures talk about various information about manufacturing and assembling. It is all on a powerpoint, so I mainly read the powerpoint instead of going to the lecture.

3. Pedal Kart Design
In some of the lab sessions will talk about this. Details will be put onto the grading and workload part.
reviews.comment_teaching: I do not have many things to say about the professor, anyway he is good in representing the things on the powerpoint clearly, and TAs in lab session are helpful too.
reviews.comment_grading:
Due to the pandemic the grading is as follows:

20% Quiz (2 x 10%)
80% Project (Report + Presentation)

The quiz is done in an online proctored mode where you have to put a camera in a unaccessable location on your small desk so that your camera can both view your face and the computer screen. The quiz is not very hard, but it requires you to memorize almost every tiny details on the powerpoint.

The project is spilt into 3 parts. I do not exactly remember the grading percentages, but it includes 1 individual report + 1 group report + 1 group presentation. So if you are not required to take this course and you cannot find friends to take together, please go away.

The project is as trash as you can imagine. Details on workload part.

Grading is not yet being released when I write this, but I can expect what it will be.
reviews.comment_workload:
This is where the course become complete shit.
The quizzes do not require a lot of time to do revision so I will put this aside.

The project contributes to 80% of your total grading and consists of 3 parts.

1. Phase I (Individual report)
This is the easier part, where you have to design a pedal kart to join the 24-hr pedal kart grand prix in Hong Kong, and submit a 40 page report about it.
In this stage you have to give relevant information, related technologies, and detailed design on your pedal kart. You need to include some hand drawing and sketches to interpret your idea. I spend about 4-5 days to rush this, since you have to go find all of the relevant technologies, and each system of your kart like steering, wheels, chassis et cetera, and you have to include a multiple version of each system and then evaluate which one is the best on your kart.

2. Phase II (Group Report)
In this part you will form groups with 3-4 people, and then design a pedal kart out of almost thin air. This time you cannot include your ugly hand sketches, but instead 3D drawings and detailed specifications, also manufacturing methods and assembly considerations, and you need to compress them to about 50 pages.
The major workload comes from the 3D drawing. Without much knowledge from the solidworks, and this requires us to design a complex pedal kart, with many functions such as making gears not yet learned.
